hypothesis_content.title: Neutral-to-Stress Fade on Failed Volatility Compression Breakout
hypothesis_content.statement: During extended NEUTRAL regimes (BTC 20-day realized volatility < 40%), a sharp 1-day price breakout (>5%) on low volume (<90% of 20-day avg volume) that fails to hold the next day will revert and trigger a short-term STRESS regime, favoring short-term mean reversion shorts on overextended alts (e.g., PEPE, DOGE).
hypothesis_content.rationale: Low-volatility neutral environments often see weak, low-conviction breakouts that trap late buyers. A failure to sustain the move on follow-through day indicates lack of institutional participation, leading to rapid profit-taking and a spike in short-term volatility (Stress). Overextended memecoins are most vulnerable.
entry_conditions: Regime == NEUTRAL for at least 15 days
BTC has a 1-day up move >5% on volume < 90% of its 20-day average
BTC fails to hold gains: next day's close is in bottom 50% of day1 range
High-beta altcoin (PEPE, DOGE) 1-day RSI(14) > 70 on same move

exit_conditions.take_profit: Target 1: Altcoin price retraces 50% of its breakout move. Target 2: BTC 1-day RSI(14) falls below 45
exit_conditions.stop_loss: BTC closes above the high of the initial breakout candle

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: More than 60% of such low-volume breakouts are followed by continued upward momentum and increasing volume, invalidating the mean reception premise.
